awd_titl_txt: Becoming Engaged Engineering Scholars: Success Programs for Recruitment and Retention in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need in STEM fields.  This S-STEM project at Western Washington University aims to recruit and retain undergraduates in engineering.  Over its five years of funding, this project will fund 48 scholarships to first-year undergraduate students, providing them with an average of $6,250 of financial support in their first and second years.   The Scholars will be recruited in four groups, in the first four years of the project.  Students in the new Western Washington University engineering program have not been retained at high levels.  This project will provide a systematic sequence of academic, social, and career support services specifically designed to enhance the success of engineering students during these first two years of undergraduate study. The primary project goal is to ensure the engineering programs offer an equitable pathway into engineering careers, particularly for low-income students in the State of Washington. In addition to providing financial support for participants, the project will adapt existing support structures to offer a one-week bridge program prior to the start of their first year, implement a multi-level mentoring system that includes internal and external mentors, engage Scholars in multiple curricular and co-curricular activities including an engaged engineering project experience, create a first-year seminar focused on engineering and society, and employ an education researcher and an external evaluator throughout the project to study its impact.

The primary goals of this project are to: (1) Provide S-STEM Scholars with inclusive, evidence-based structured support that is responsive to their academic, social, and career development needs as they progress through the first and second years in the engineering programs; and (2) Generate empirical knowledge about the impact of the sequence of evidence-based interventions, and how they alter the self-efficacy, identity, and retention of S-STEM Scholars within the engineering programs.  The project will use evidence-based approaches that have been shown to improve recruitment and retention of traditionally underrepresented groups in engineering.  To assess the impact, the project will include a mixed methods quasi-experimental study design with a matched comparison group.  The project has the potential to contribute to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce by preparing students for careers in engineering.  Moreover, the findings and knowledge generated from this project can benefit other institutions looking to implement similar programs, and will be especially useful for engineering technology departments contemplating a transition to engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Becoming Engaged Engineering Scholars (BEES) program at Western Washington University provided comprehensive support and scholarships to help talented low-income students succeed in engineering. Over five years, the program supported four cohorts of students through their first two years of engineering study, combining financial assistance with targeted academic and social support.

The program had two main goals: 1) To provide evidence-based support that responds to students' academic, social, and career development needs, and 2) To study how these supports impact students' confidence, identity as engineers, and sense of belonging in engineering.

Key program elements included:

  • A week-long summer bridge program that evolved from math-focused preparation to hands-on projects in the engineering makerspace
  • Coordinated first-year courses where scholars took math, physics and engineering classes together as a cohort
  • Multi-level mentoring from faculty, peers, and industry professionals
  • Social events and community-building activities
  • Access to makerspaces and hands-on engineering projects

The program successfully recruited and retained a diverse group of engineering students. Compared to the overall engineering department, BEES scholars were more likely to be women (33% vs 20%), people of color (55% vs 32%), first-generation college students (43% vs 21%), and from low-income backgrounds qualifying for federal Pell grants (61% vs 21%).

Research findings showed that BEES scholars were far more likely to persist in engineering compared to similar non-BEES students. By the end of their second year, 61% of BEES scholars had been admitted to an engineering major, compared to only 24-28% of non-BEES students. The program was particularly impactful for women students, who reported higher levels of belonging in engineering compared to women who were not in the program.

Several program elements have been permanently adopted by the engineering department, creating lasting positive change. The first-year engineering seminar is now required for all engineering students, the summer bridge program has been institutionalized and opened to all incoming engineering students, and the improved math placement assessment communication strategies are used department-wide.

The first cohort of BEES scholars graduated in June 2023, with 60% being women and/or students of color. These graduates are pursuing diverse paths including graduate school and industry positions. Through careful study of program impacts, the BEES project has contributed valuable insights about supporting undergraduate engineering student success, particularly for students from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in engineering. These findings have been shared through multiple conference presentations and publications to help inform similar efforts at other institutions.

The project demonstrates how targeted support combining scholarships, academic preparation, hands-on experiences, and community building can create more equitable pathways into engineering careers while advancing knowledge about effective practices in engineering education.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2025
Modified by: Jill Davishahl
